metadata.author: Sherin Ramadan Hamad, Mehrez E. El-Naggar
metadata.title: Blocking of gastric acid induced histopathological alterations, enhancing of DNA content and proliferation of goblet cells in the acute lung injury mice models by nano-fenugreek oral administration
affiliations: Histopathological Department, National Organization for Drug Control and Research (NODCAR), Giza, Egypt;
Textile Research Division, National Research Centre, Giza, Egypt
metadata.abstract: This current study aimed at detecting the potential protective role of nano-fenugreek seed on acute lung injury (ALI) induced by instillation gastric acid in male Swiss albino mice using histological and histochemical studies. Forty animals were grouped as follows: control group, HCl-treated group, low nano-fenugreek + HCl treated group, and high nano-fenugreek + HCl treated group. Pretreatment with nano-fenugreek in animal model of ALI resulted in marked ameliorations of the lung histological lesions and injury induced by HCL instillation in a dose dependent manner. It also caused inhibition in the increase of the DNA content and prevented proliferation of goblet cells induced by HCl instillation alone. In conclusion, pretreatment with Nano-fenugreek prior induction ALI could be suppress the aggregations of inflammatory cells, enhancing of DNA content, and proliferation of goblet cells induced by gastric acid in a dose dependent manner. We suggest that Nano-fenugreek may be useful in combating lung injury.

methods:
Chemicals

HCL was obtained from Sigma Aldrich. While fenugreek seeds were obtained from local supermarket as powder and prepared in nanoparticle form according to method of Hebeish et al (2014). The particle shape and size were assessed by Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM). The diluted samples were picked up on carbon coated copper grids (CCG) and examined by a JEOL-JEM 1010 Transmission Electron Microscope; made in Japan, at 80KV, at the Regional Center for Mycology and Biotechnology (RCMB), Al-Azhar University.

Animals and ethics

Forty male Swiss albino mice of 25–30 g weight and 9–12 weeks were used. Animals were supplied by the animal house of National Organization for Drug Control and Research (NODCAR) in Giza, Egypt. In laboratory plastic cages, the animals were kept under standard condition and allowed for free access of water adlibitum and standard diet. Before beginning the experiment, all animals were acclimatized twice a week. All male Swiss albino mice were grouped and housed according to the guidelines of the institutional animal’s ethics committee of NODCAR. All the experimental procedures were carried out in accordance with international guidelines for the care and use of laboratory animals.
results:
Transmission electron microscope of nano-fenugreek

Transmission Electron Microscope image analysis shown that nano-fenugreek is spherical in shape and average size within the range of 32–65 nm in diameter. All nanoparticles have a rough surface and definite spherical shape (Figure 1).

Detection DNA content (feulgen’s stain) in lung tissues

For demonstrating DNA content, lung sections were stained with Feulgen’s reaction to demonstrate DNA as magenta color. Lung sections from the control group showed normal DNA contents (Figure 3(A)). However, mice instilled with HCL revealed increase contents of DNA as evidenced by high magenta color (Figure 3(B)) compared with control group (Figure 3(A)). While group pretreated with fenugreek nanoparticles prior instillation of HCL prevented the increase in content of DNA observed in HCL treated animals, in a dose dependent manner. DNA content showed more decrease in the group pretreated with high dose of fenugreek nanoparticles (Figure 3(D)) compared with that pretreated with low dose of fenugreek nanoparticles (Figure 3(C)).
discussion:
Our main aim was to evaluate the effectives of nano-fenugreek on a model of ALI induced by gastric acid. Our results demonstrated that instillation of HCL in lung can cause acute lung inflammation and edema, these agreed with work done by Matute-Bello et al 2008 and Zhang et al 2018. These pathological changes could be due to elevate TNF-α, IL-1β and IL-6 level (Zhang et al 2018) and increase of MDA level.

The cytokines such as TNF-α, IL-1β and IL-6 may cause lung inflammation, facilitate interaction between neutrophils and special cytokines and release reactive oxygen metabolites, which become worse with increase of neutrophils (Larrick and Kunkel 1988; Strieter et al 1999; Vlahakis et al 1999). Higher TNF-α, IL-1β and IL-6 levels in serum or lung lead to higher incidence and severity of ARDS, resulting in higher mortality rate (Larrick and Kunkel 1988; Moldoveanu et al 2009). MDA is an aldehyde substance produced in free radical-induced lipid peroxidation, which can indirectly reflect the degree of oxidative damage (Tariq et al 2003).

ethical_compliance: All the experimental procedures were carried out in accordance with international guidelines for the care and use of laboratory animals
introduction: The early stage of ALI is characterized by pulmonary edema due to vasoconstriction of blood vessels in the lung (Piantadosi and Schwartz 2004) and the advancement of ALI is characterized by enhanced production of chemokines and pro-inflammatory agents such as interleukin-1 (IL-1), IL-6, and tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α), followed by recruitment of neutrophils in the lungs (Dushianthan et al 2011). Instillation of hydrochloric acid is considered as one of the experimental modules for ALI (Fukunaga et al 2005; Eickmeier et al 2013; Eickmeier et al 2014; Kaur et al 2018).

From last years, researchers have used natural products to treat/prevent various diseases. Recently, researches also go in synthesizing nanoparticles from various natural products (Bharali et al 2011). Nanomaterial is a particle of size ranging between 1 nm and 100 nm as recorded by many studies (Auffan et al 2009). Nanoparticles forms have high capability to manipulate particles in order to target specific areas of the body and control the release of drugs (Watkins et al 2015). Fenugreek (Trigonella foenum graecum) seeds, one of the herbal medicines in the world, which used for tonic, carminative, aphrodisiac effects (Xue et al 2007) and widely used as spice in food preparations in India, China, Middle East, Egypt, Ethiopia and in oriental countries due to their strong flavor and aroma (Kaviarasan et al 2007; Ghedira et al 2010). It also stimulates appetite and activates lung, breathing and lung secretion as well as used as clearance the voice and stimulates menstruation (Azam Khan and Azam 2004; Alavi Khorasani 2018). Fenugreek dose has a wide range. In one human study, daily 25 g of powder from fenugreek seed was good tolerated and no serious side effects (Vijayakumar and Bhat 2008).

Abstract: This current study aimed at detecting the potential protective role of nano-fenugreek seed on acute lung injury (ALI) induced by instillation gastric acid in male Swiss albino mice using histological and histochemical studies. Forty animals were grouped as follows: control group, HCl-treated group, low nano-fenugreek + HCl treated group, and high nano-fenugreek + HCl treated group. Pretreatment with nano-fenugreek in animal model of ALI resulted in marked ameliorations of the lung histological lesions and injury induced by HCL instillation in a dose dependent manner. It also caused inhibition in the increase of the DNA content and prevented proliferation of goblet cells induced by HCl instillation alone. In conclusion, pretreatment with Nano-fenugreek prior induction ALI could be suppress the aggregations of inflammatory cells, enhancing of DNA content, and proliferation of goblet cells induced by gastric acid in a dose dependent manner. We suggest that Nano-fenugreek may be useful in combating lung injury.

The early stage of ALI is characterized by pulmonary edema due to vasoconstriction of blood vessels in the lung (Piantadosi and Schwartz 2004) and the advancement of ALI is characterized by enhanced production of chemokines and pro-inflammatory agents such as interleukin-1 (IL-1), IL-6, and tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α), followed by recruitment of neutrophils in the lungs (Dushianthan et al 2011). Instillation of hydrochloric acid is considered as one of the experimental modules for ALI (Fukunaga et al 2005; Eickmeier et al 2013; Eickmeier et al 2014; Kaur et al 2018).

From last years, researchers have used natural products to treat/prevent various diseases. Recently, researches also go in synthesizing nanoparticles from various natural products (Bharali et al 2011). Nanomaterial is a particle of size ranging between 1 nm and 100 nm as recorded by many studies (Auffan et al 2009). Nanoparticles forms have high capability to manipulate particles in order to target specific areas of the body and control the release of drugs (Watkins et al 2015). Fenugreek (Trigonella foenum graecum) seeds, one of the herbal medicines in the world, which used for tonic, carminative, aphrodisiac effects (Xue et al 2007) and widely used as spice in food preparations in India, China, Middle East, Egypt, Ethiopia and in oriental countries due to their strong flavor and aroma (Kaviarasan et al 2007; Ghedira et al 2010). It also stimulates appetite and activates lung, breathing and lung secretion as well as used as clearance the voice and stimulates menstruation (Azam Khan and Azam 2004; Alavi Khorasani 2018). Fenugreek dose has a wide range. In one human study, daily 25 g of powder from fenugreek seed was good tolerated and no serious side effects (Vijayakumar and Bhat 2008).

This study was designed to investigate the efficacy of the nanoparticle form of T. foenum-graecum (Fenugreek) to protect against ALI induced by HCL in model animals. We examined histological structural of lung, and analyzed DNA content as well as determined goblet cell in lung tissues.
Materials and methods: HCL was obtained from Sigma Aldrich. While fenugreek seeds were obtained from local supermarket as powder and prepared in nanoparticle form according to method of Hebeish et al (2014). The particle shape and size were assessed by Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM). The diluted samples were picked up on carbon coated copper grids (CCG) and examined by a JEOL-JEM 1010 Transmission Electron Microscope; made in Japan, at 80KV, at the Regional Center for Mycology and Biotechnology (RCMB), Al-Azhar University.

Forty male Swiss albino mice of 25–30 g weight and 9–12 weeks were used. Animals were supplied by the animal house of National Organization for Drug Control and Research (NODCAR) in Giza, Egypt. In laboratory plastic cages, the animals were kept under standard condition and allowed for free access of water adlibitum and standard diet. Before beginning the experiment, all animals were acclimatized twice a week. All male Swiss albino mice were grouped and housed according to the guidelines of the institutional animal’s ethics committee of NODCAR. All the experimental procedures were carried out in accordance with international guidelines for the care and use of laboratory animals.

The animals in the experimental were grouped into four groups, (n = 10). The first group served as control animals and was instilled with saline into lung; the second group served as model of ALI and instilled HCL into the lung (2 ml/kg, 0.1N hydrochloric acid (HCl)) according to Zhang et al (2018); the third group were pretreated orally with fenugreek nanoparticle at dose 2.5 mg/kg.bw and instilled HCL into the lung (2 ml/kg, 0.1N HCl); and the fourth group were pretreated with fenugreek nanoparticle at dose 5 mg/kg.bw and instilled HCL into the lung (2 ml/kg, 0.1N HCl).

The period of experimental 73 h, fenugreek nanoparticle orally administrated at 0, 24, 48 and 72 h while HCL was instilled once one hour after last administration of fenugreek nanoparticle administration. All animals were sacrificed one hour after hydrochloric acid instillation.

Animals administrated orally with nano-fenugreek seeds at one dose levels 5, 50, 300 or 2000 mg/kg body weight and observed any clinical changes for 14 days after the administration (OECD guideline for testing of chemicals 2001). No mortality, body weight changes were observed for all above doses. So, the chosen safe dose of Nano-fenugreek was ≤2000 mg/kgbw.
Results: Transmission Electron Microscope image analysis shown that nano-fenugreek is spherical in shape and average size within the range of 32–65 nm in diameter. All nanoparticles have a rough surface and definite spherical shape (Figure 1).

For demonstrating DNA content, lung sections were stained with Feulgen’s reaction to demonstrate DNA as magenta color. Lung sections from the control group showed normal DNA contents (Figure 3(A)). However, mice instilled with HCL revealed increase contents of DNA as evidenced by high magenta color (Figure 3(B)) compared with control group (Figure 3(A)). While group pretreated with fenugreek nanoparticles prior instillation of HCL prevented the increase in content of DNA observed in HCL treated animals, in a dose dependent manner. DNA content showed more decrease in the group pretreated with high dose of fenugreek nanoparticles (Figure 3(D)) compared with that pretreated with low dose of fenugreek nanoparticles (Figure 3(C)).
Discussion: Our main aim was to evaluate the effectives of nano-fenugreek on a model of ALI induced by gastric acid. Our results demonstrated that instillation of HCL in lung can cause acute lung inflammation and edema, these agreed with work done by Matute-Bello et al 2008 and Zhang et al 2018. These pathological changes could be due to elevate TNF-α, IL-1β and IL-6 level (Zhang et al 2018) and increase of MDA level.

The cytokines such as TNF-α, IL-1β and IL-6 may cause lung inflammation, facilitate interaction between neutrophils and special cytokines and release reactive oxygen metabolites, which become worse with increase of neutrophils (Larrick and Kunkel 1988; Strieter et al 1999; Vlahakis et al 1999). Higher TNF-α, IL-1β and IL-6 levels in serum or lung lead to higher incidence and severity of ARDS, resulting in higher mortality rate (Larrick and Kunkel 1988; Moldoveanu et al 2009). MDA is an aldehyde substance produced in free radical-induced lipid peroxidation, which can indirectly reflect the degree of oxidative damage (Tariq et al 2003).

In addition, the observed increase of DNA content and severe goblet cells proliferations in the present study in lung of animals instilled with HCL could be attributed to the observed marked aggregations of inflammatory cells in present work and work done by El-Refaiy and Eissa (2012).

We also recorded that orally supplementation of nano-fenugreek prior HCL instillation in lung was able to inhibit ALI, histological lung injury, and inflammation and edema in dose dependent manner. nano-fenugreek also attenuated DNA content and goblet cells proliferations compared to HCL group. These were in agree with work done by Emtiazy et al (2018).

In different studies, antioxidant effect of the fenugreek attributed to its flavonoids compound, which has ability to inhibit lipid peroxidation and protect the airways against oxidative stress (Rice-Evans 2001; Schroeter et al 2002). The activation of basophils and mast cells were inhibited by flavonoids (Naidu et al 2011). In addition, Emtiazy et al (2018) hypothesized that consumption of fenugreek syrup (aqueous extract of fenugreek seeds) by mild asthma patients could improve the function of lung and life quality as well as decrease in serum cytokine IL-4 levels in patients with mild asthma.

Further, Yacoubi et al (2011), reported that polyphenol components in fenugreek seed were responsible for the return of the oxidant/antioxidant balance. He proved that polyphenolic components present in fenugreek have high ability to scavenge free radical (by evaluates the scavenging of the free radical 2,2-diphenyl-1-picrylhydrazyl), and suppress malonaldehyde production. Also, Vyas et al (2008) who reported that phenolic extract of fenugreek has a potent anti-inflammatory activity.

In the present study, the potential protective effect of nano-fenugreek could be also attributed to its nanoparticle form. Particle sizes of nanoparticles materials is between 100 nm and 300 nm, so have a high surface area and have high capability to target in specific areas of the body in vitro and in vivo (Watkins et al 2015; Hill and Li 2017). Another reason for protection action of fenugreek seeds is due to mucilage component of fenugreek seeds (28%) that stimulates secretions of lung and ameliorate asthmatic cough (Razi 2001; Azam Khan and Azam 2004; Alavi Khorasani 2018).

participants.context: This current study aimed at detecting the potential protective role of nano-fenugreek seed on acute lung injury (ALI) induced by instillation gastric acid in male Swiss albino mice using histological and histochemical studies. <mark class="stats">Forty animals were grouped as follows: control group, HCl-treated group, low nano-fenugreek + HCl treated group, and high nano-fenugreek + HCl treated group</mark>. Pretreatment with nano-fenugreek in animal model of ALI resulted in marked ameliorations of the lung histological lesions and injury induced by HCL instillation in a dose dependent manner

The particle shape and size were assessed by Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM). The diluted samples were picked up on carbon coated copper grids (CCG) and examined by a JEOL-JEM 1010 Transmission Electron Microscope; made in Japan, at 80KV, at the Regional Center for Mycology and Biotechnology (RCMB), Al-Azhar University.

Animals and ethics

Forty male Swiss albino mice of 25–30 g weight and 9–12 weeks were used. Animals were supplied by the animal house of National Organization for Drug Control and Research (NODCAR) in Giza, Egypt

Animals and ethics. <mark class="stats">Forty male Swiss albino mice of 25–30 g weight and 9–12 weeks were used</mark>. Animals were supplied by the animal house of National Organization for Drug Control and Research (NODCAR) in Giza, Egypt

All the experimental procedures were carried out in accordance with international guidelines for the care and use of laboratory animals. The animals in the experimental were grouped into four groups, (n = 10). The first group served as control animals and was instilled with saline into lung; the second group served as model of ALI and instilled HCL into the lung (2 ml/kg, 0.1N hydrochloric acid (HCl)) according to Zhang et al (2018); the third group were pretreated orally with fenugreek nanoparticle at dose 2.5 mg/kg.bw and instilled HCL into the lung (2 ml/kg, 0.1N HCl); and the fourth group were pretreated with fenugreek nanoparticle at dose 5 mg/kg.bw and instilled HCL into the lung (2 ml/kg, 0.1N HCl)

keywords: National Organization for Drug Control and Research
Regional Center for Mycology and Biotechnology
summary:
Introduction:

The early stage of ALI is characterized by pulmonary edema due to vasoconstriction of blood vessels in the lung (Piantadosi and Schwartz 2004) and the advancement of ALI is characterized by enhanced production of chemokines and pro-inflammatory agents such as interleukin-1 (IL-1), IL-6, and tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α), followed by recruitment of neutrophils in the lungs (Dushianthan et al 2011).

Fenugreek (Trigonella foenum graecum) seeds, one of the herbal medicines in the world, which used for tonic, carminative, aphrodisiac effects (Xue et al 2007) and widely used as spice in food preparations in India, China, Middle East, Egypt, Ethiopia and in oriental countries due to their strong flavor and aroma (Kaviarasan et al 2007; Ghedira et al 2010)
It stimulates appetite and activates lung, breathing and lung secretion as well as used as clearance the voice and stimulates menstruation (Azam Khan and Azam 2004; Alavi Khorasani 2018).
Daily 25 g of powder from fenugreek seed was good tolerated and no serious side effects (Vijayakumar and Bhat 2008)

Methods:

The diluted samples were picked up on carbon coated copper grids (CCG) and examined by a JEOL-JEM 1010 Transmission Electron Microscope; made in Japan, at 80KV, at the Regional Center for Mycology and Biotechnology (RCMB), Al-Azhar University.
Forty male Swiss albino mice of 25–30 g weight and 9–12 weeks were used.
All male Swiss albino mice were grouped and housed according to the guidelines of the institutional animal’s ethics committee of NODCAR.
All the experimental procedures were carried out in accordance with international guidelines for the care and use of laboratory animals

Results:

Transmission Electron Microscope image analysis shown that nano-fenugreek is spherical in shape and average size within the range of 32–65 nm in diameter.
Lung sections from the control group showed normal DNA contents (Figure 3(A)).
Mice instilled with HCL revealed increase contents of DNA as evidenced by high magenta color (Figure 3(B)) compared with control group (Figure 3(A)).
While group pretreated with fenugreek nanoparticles prior instillation of HCL prevented the increase in content of DNA observed in HCL treated animals, in a dose dependent manner.
DNA content showed more decrease in the group pretreated with high dose of fenugreek nanoparticles (Figure 3(D)) compared with that pretreated with low dose of fenugreek nanoparticles (Figure 3(C))

Conclusion:

The authors' main aim was to evaluate the effectives of nano-fenugreek on a model of ALI induced by gastric acid.
The authors' results demonstrated that instillation of HCL in lung can cause acute lung inflammation and edema, these agreed with work done by Matute-Bello et al 2008 and Zhang et al 2018
These pathological changes could be due to elevate TNF-α, IL-1β and IL-6 level (Zhang et al 2018) and increase of MDA level.
MDA is an aldehyde substance produced in free radical-induced lipid peroxidation, which can indirectly reflect the degree of oxidative damage (Tariq et al 2003)

claims: We examined histological structural of lung, and analyzed DNA content as well as determined goblet cell in lung tissues
Our results demonstrated that instillation of HCL in lung can cause acute lung inflammation and edema, these agreed with work done by Matute-Bello et al 2008 and Zhang et al 2018
key_statements: The early stage of acute lung injury is characterized by pulmonary edema due to vasoconstriction of blood vessels in the lung (Piantadosi and Schwartz 2004) and the advancement of acute lung injury is characterized by enhanced production of chemokines and pro-inflammatory agents such as interleukin-1 (IL-1), IL-6, and tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α), followed by recruitment of neutrophils in the lungs (Dushianthan et al 2011)
Transmission Electron Microscope image analysis shown that nano-fenugreek is spherical in shape and average size within the range of 32–65 nm in diameter
DNA content showed more decrease in the group pretreated with high dose of fenugreek nanoparticles (Figure 3(D)) compared with that pretreated with low dose of fenugreek nanoparticles (Figure 3(C))
Our main aim was to evaluate the effectives of nano-fenugreek on a model of acute lung injury induced by gastric acid

Our results demonstrated that instillation of HCL in lung can cause acute lung inflammation and edema, these agreed with work done by Matute-Bello et al 2008 and Zhang et al 2018. These pathological changes could be due to elevate TNF-α, IL-1β and IL-6 level (Zhang et al 2018) and increase of MDA level

Our results demonstrated that instillation of HCL in lung can cause acute lung inflammation and edema, these agreed with work done by Matute-Bello et al 2008 and Zhang et al 2018. These pathological changes could be due to elevate TNF-α, IL-1β and IL-6 level (Zhang et al 2018) and increase of MDA level. The cytokines such as TNF-α, IL-1β and IL-6 may cause lung inflammation, facilitate interaction between neutrophils and special cytokines and release reactive oxygen metabolites, which become worse with increase of neutrophils (Larrick and Kunkel 1988; Strieter et al 1999; Vlahakis et al 1999)
